title: ALDS Game 3: Rays stay alive with power surge in rout of Astros; Justin Verlander to start Game 4
text:
CLOSE

The Tampa Bay Rays will live to play another day, beating the Houston Astros 10-3 at Tropicana Field to send the American League Division Series to a fourth game.

The Rays jumped on Astros starter Zack Greinke, who lasted only 3 ⅔ innings, giving up six runs on 61 pitches. Center fielder Kevin Kiermaier got things started with a three-run shot off Greinke in the second, with Ji-Man Choi and Brendan Lowe adding solo homers in the third and fourth.

Rays starter Charlie Morton was dominant against his former team, giving up just one run with nine strikeouts in five innings in Monday afternoon's win.

After failing to put the series away, Astros manager A.J. Hinch announced that Justin Verlander will start Tuesday's Game 4 on three days' rest. Verlander threw seven shutout innings in a Game 1 win.

"Five-game series are pretty crazy. You never know what can happen," Verlander said postgame. "You can't put all your eggs in one basket and say 'well if we lose tomorrow we've got Justin and Gerrit (Cole) for Game 5.'"

BOX SCORE: Rays 10, Astros 3

YANKEES: Severino's return gives Bombers a huge boost

Turning point

With a runner on second and two outs in the second inning, Greinke hit Travis d'Arnaud with a 1-1 fastball, bringing Kiermaier to the plate. Greinke fell behind 2-0 on Kiermaier and then left a changeup up in the zone, which Tampa's center fielder crushed to center field for a three-run homer.

All three home runs surrendered by the 35-year-old Greinke were on secondary pitches – changeups to Kiermaier and Choi and a curveball for Lowe.

Tampa batted around in that fourth inning, scoring four runs to expand the lead to 8-1.

Kevin Kiermaier celebrates his three-run homer in the second with teammate Avisail Garcia. (Photo: Kim Klement, Kim Klement-USA TODAY Sports)

Manager's special

Trailing 5-1 with two on and two out in the fourth, Hinch brought in lefty Wade Miley to face Austin Meadows, hoping to the game within reach.

Miley gave up a two-run double to Meadows and another run after that. He ended up throwing 62 pitches in 2⅔ innings.

Miley was Houston's presumed Game 4 starter, so it's interesting that the Astros burned him trailing by four runs in a bit of speculative situation. It wasn't necessarily the wrong move – since the 32-year-old held left-handed hitters to a .207 average this season – but it forced his hand into selecting Verlander as the Game 4 starter.

Man of the moment

Five days after winning the wild-card game, Morton beat his former team to keep the Rays alive.

The 35-year-old got into trouble in the first, giving up a solo home run to Jose Altuve and then finding himself with runners on the corners and two outs after a walk and error. But Morton got Yuli Gurriel to pop out and a threat that could have resulted in a couple more runs.

In his career, Morton is now 4-0 with 0.95 ERA in elimination games.

State of the series

The Astros get another chance to close things out on the road Tuesday, but it's not going to be a straight-forward game. Tampa is expected to do a bullpen game, though Game 1 starter Tyler Glasnow may be available to throw a few innings.
description: Tampa hit four home runs in a 10-3 win in Game 3 of the ALDS, keeping their season alive for at least one more day.
